paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does the Earth-sized rocky planet TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation from its M dwarf host star, as probed by JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b Phase-Curve Observation
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Single planet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over a complete orbital phase curve measuring thermal emission variations

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-Rock No-Atmosphere Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Theoretical model assuming no atmosphere with minimal heat redistribution, serving as the baseline comparison case

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-Rich Atmosphere Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model with significant CO2 greenhouse gas absorption, testing whether spectral structure supports atmospheric composition

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-Rich Atmosphere Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized atmospheric composition scenario with weaker CO2 signature constraints, providing comparison for composition assumptions

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets
Retrieval assumptions including circulation patterns, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posterior distributions
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can potentially bias weak spectral feature measurements
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current JWST MIRI dataset
